headline: Tesla debuts 'affordable' versions of Models Y and 3
summary: STORY: Tesla revealed a lower-cost version of its best-selling Model Y SUV and Model 3 sedan on Tuesday in a bid to put its falling sales in reverse.The electric vehicle maker said Tuesday the new SUV starts at just under $40,000, while the sedan starts at around $37,000.They're calling the new models "Standard" versions, which have no Autosteer, driver assistance or rear passenger touchscreens.They'll also have less powerful acceleration than the current models, which Tesla is now calling Premium.CEO Elon Musk has promised mass-market Teslas for years but canceled plans last year to build an all-new car set at an even lower price point, $25,000.Then last October he said they would be priced below what he called a ‘key threshold’ of $30,000 once the US EV tax credit was factored in.Last month, the tax credit ended, effectively raising prices.That’s what helped send Tesla’s deliveries to the record levels it announced last week.But now, unless these cheaper models come to the rescue, its expected sales will slow down for the rest of the year.Affordable cars like it will be key to Tesla delivering 20 million vehicles over the next decade.That’s one of several goals set by the company’s board as part of its proposed $1 trillion pay package for Musk.

raw.headline: Tesla debuts 'affordable' versions of Models Y and 3
raw.summary: STORY: Tesla revealed a lower-cost version of its best-selling Model Y SUV and Model 3 sedan on Tuesday in a bid to put its falling sales in reverse.The electric vehicle maker said Tuesday the new SUV starts at just under $40,000, while the sedan starts at around $37,000.They're calling the new models "Standard" versions, which have no Autosteer, driver assistance or rear passenger touchscreens.They'll also have less powerful acceleration than the current models, which Tesla is now calling Premium.CEO Elon Musk has promised mass-market Teslas for years but canceled plans last year to build an all-new car set at an even lower price point, $25,000.Then last October he said they would be priced below what he called a ‘key threshold’ of $30,000 once the US EV tax credit was factored in.Last month, the tax credit ended, effectively raising prices.That’s what helped send Tesla’s deliveries to the record levels it announced last week.But now, unless these cheaper models come to the rescue, its expected sales will slow down for the rest of the year.Affordable cars like it will be key to Tesla delivering 20 million vehicles over the next decade.That’s one of several goals set by the company’s board as part of its proposed $1 trillion pay package for Musk.

headline: Auto delinquencies are surging across income levels: VantageScore
summary: Auto loan delinquencies have soared by more than 50% over the last 15 years, according to a new VantageScore report, making them one of the riskiest products for consumer credit scores. VantageScore chief economist Rikard Bandebo sits down with Josh Lipton to talk more about the data and affordability issues in auto loans. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend.

headline: Joby, Archer Aviation Stocks Drop. Tesla’s News Was Only About EVs.
summary: Shares of the pair, which make electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) aircraft, dropped on Tuesday after an announcement from Tesla turned out to be only about cars, as generally expected.  A tweet about Tuesday’s announcement included a video showing a spinning wheel with a Tesla logo that could have been the rotor of a Tesla eVTOL, or quadcopter drone.  Tesla stock rose 5.1% in anticipation of the news and fell 4.4% on Tuesday, leaving shares up about $3 for the week.

A tweet about Tuesday’s announcement included a video showing a spinning wheel with a Tesla logo that could have been the rotor of a Tesla eVTOL, or quadcopter drone.  Tesla stock rose 5.1% in anticipation of the news and fell 4.4% on Tuesday, leaving shares up about $3 for the week.

headline: Tesla offers more affordable Model Y starting at $39,990
summary: Investing.com -- Tesla launched a lower-priced version of its popular Model Y SUV on Tuesday, with a starting price of $39,990, reducing the entry point by $5,000 from its prior MSRP of $44,990. This move follows the expiration of $7,500 U.S. EV tax break at the end of last month, which effectively immediately raised prices for consumers.

headline: Tesla offers cheaper versions of 2 electric vehicles in bid to win back market share in tough year
summary: Tesla rolled out new, cheaper versions of two of its electric car models on Tuesday in hopes the offerings will help revive flagging sales.  The new Model Y, costing just under $40,000 with a stripped-down interior, follows a slump in Tesla sales covering most of the past year due to anti-Elon Musk boycotts targeting the company.  Tesla stock fell more than 2.5% to $441.08 in late afternoon trading Tuesday.

The new Model Y, costing just under $40,000 with a stripped-down interior, follows a slump in Tesla sales covering most of the past year due to anti-Elon Musk boycotts targeting the company.  Tesla stock fell more than 2.5% to $441.08 in late afternoon trading Tuesday.

headline: Tesla Stock Drops
summary: Tesla stock was down 3.1% in afternoon trading after the lower-priced models showed up on Tesla’s website. That still puts shares roughly $10 above the level before Tesla teased the reveal at the beginning of the week.

headline: Tesla unveils lower-cost Model Y in drive to reignite sales
summary: (Reuters) -Tesla unveiled a more affordable version of its best-selling Model Y SUV on Tuesday starting at $39,990, as the electric-vehicle maker seeks to reverse falling sales and waning market share amid rising global competition.  Chief Executive Elon Musk has for years promised mass-market vehicles, though last year he canceled plans to build an all-new $25,000 EV, Reuters first reported.  Late last year, Musk said the vehicle would be priced below the "key threshold" of $30,000 including U.S. EV tax credits.

raw.headline: Tesla unveils lower-cost Model Y in drive to reignite sales
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Tesla unveiled a more affordable version of its best-selling Model Y SUV on Tuesday starting at $39,990, as the electric-vehicle maker seeks to reverse falling sales and waning market share amid rising global competition.  Chief Executive Elon Musk has for years promised mass-market vehicles, though last year he canceled plans to build an all-new $25,000 EV, Reuters first reported.  Late last year, Musk said the vehicle would be priced below the "key threshold" of $30,000 including U.S. EV tax credits.

headline: How the Stock Might React to the News
summary: There really is no hard and fast rule of thumb to project how Tesla stock reacts to news about products product or investor events.  All investors can do is arm themselves with some historical context.  In general, the pattern shows what seasoned investors already know: The stock market is forward looking and investors “buy the rumor and sell the news.”

summary: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are rising in Tuesday's pre-market trading after Advanced Micro Devices' (AMD) deal with OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) stirred up a rally yesterday; gold prices (GC=F) toe the line of crossing above $4,000 per ounce as the metal continues its record run. As the government shutdown stretches into its seventh day, President Trump is floating the idea of entering negotiations with Democratic leaders over health care policy. Tesla (TSLA) is expected to unveil a cheaper version of its Model Y electric vehicle at an event today after teasing the product launch on social media on Monday. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.
